Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Surgical Cognitive Simulation Training in Surgical Trainees

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to an intervention group receiving SCS training or a control group with no training.

Participants.evidence: general surgical trainees in years 3–5 from the West Midlands Deanery

Intervention.evidence: intervention group receiving SCS training or a control group with no training

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of surgical cognitive simulation (SCS) training in improving surgical skills.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in procedure-based assessment scores, measured over four months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a random number generator

Blinding.evidence: outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of 21 participants recruited between January and June 2021, 10 were randomised to the intervention group and 11 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Complete data were available for 7 participants in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a statistically significant improvement in 11 of 16 assessment domains (P < 0.050) and a mean reduction in procedure time (–15.98 vs. –1.14 min; P = 0.024).

Funding.evidence: Supported by Health Education England (West Midlands) and the Alan Turing Institute.
